Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT0530-UPDATE-COX 
    

      UPDATE
      Adds: COKE-LAWSUIT; GINGRICH-BUSINESSMAN
      Deletes: POL-TICKER; FBN-VOLS; BBN-WINTER
      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR TUESDAY, May 30, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   INTERNATIONAL

   LEBANON-PRISON _ BEIRUT, Lebanon _ Until she her release during
the Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon, Journalism student Cosette
Ibrihim spent 9 months in the notorious Al-Khaim prison, run by
Israel's allies, the South Lebanon Army. She said that as a
Christian and the objects of an international human rights cause,
she received ``lenient treatment'' a month of interrogations and
beatings, no trials or lawyers. ``Here,'' here captors told her,
``You defend yourself.'' Lebanese are debating whether to turn the
hill top prison into a museum or turn it into a prison for
collaborators. Inmates there in the '80s describe days chained to
electrical posts, sessions of dowsings with extremely hot or
extremely cold water. While her country celebrates Israel's
withdrawal, Ibrihim is suffering from stress, aggravated ulcers and
exhaustion. She's bitter and unsure of what to do with her life.
Developing.

   (Kaplow, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS. MOVED

   Eds.: Expected to move by 4 p.m. EDT.

   CLINTON-PORTUGAL _ LISBON, Portugal _ President Clinton arrives
here Tuesday for a state visit, to kick off a weeklong trip that
will also take him to Germany, Russia and the Ukraine. Developing.

   (Deans, c. 2000 Cox News Service).

   Eds. : Expected to move by 7 p.m. EDT in both International and
Washington categories.

   E-COLI _ TORONTO - Coverage on the most severe E.Coli outbreak
known in Canada. (McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   BUSINESS

   COKE-LAWSUIT _ ATLANTA _ With settlement talks under way,
plaintiffs' attorneys are not going to file an important document
by today's deadline in the racial discrimination lawsuit against
Coca-Cola. ``I can't talk about the settlement talks, but I can
confirm that tomorrow we are not going to file the class
certification brief, and I cannot say anything more at this time,''
plaintiffs' attorney Cyrus Mehri said Monday. (Unger, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   GINGRICH-BUSINESSMAN _ ATLANTA _ Tucked away in a back offfice
in the PriceWaterhousCoopers space of the Wildwood office park one
can find Newt Gingrich the businessman hard at work. It's far from
the pomp and circumstance of Washington D.C. where at one time
Gingrich commanded the center of the country as Speaker of the
House and architect of the Republican takeover of Congress. Yet
Gingrich's mind is as active as ever. Over the course of an
hour-and-a-half, Gingrich has mapped out a historical model of
technology and economic forces in the past century and foreshadowed
how he sees the next 25 years. (Saporta, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   REIT _ The chairman of the nation's No. 2 industrial REIT
discusses the company's strategy in Atlanta and elsewhere and the
impact e-commerce is having on industrial real estate. The REIT
develops Webvan's large centers. (Wilbert, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   INTEREST-ONLY _ A new mortgage product, the interest-only lona,
is helping home buyers with lower payments as interest rates are
rising. For the first 10 years or so, borrowers pay only the
interest, not the principal. But the principal portion on the
payment in the early years is low anyhow, and most mortgages only
have a lifespan of seven years. (Harte, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   SCHUETT-COLUMN _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio _ The closest I ever came to
knowing the joy of living in a small town, before I moved to this
one, was the neighborhood I grew up in. It was neither a suburb nor
a planned community. It was a tree-lined street of modest homes and
an endless variety of folks living on it. At the corner we had
Bader's Pharmacy, a bakery, a small grocery store, and Hodap's
Butcher Shop _ not because of some municipal visionary's blueprint,
but because they were needed. (Schuett, Cox News Service). MOVED

   YOUNG-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ Youthful rebellion takes many
forms. My first coming-of-age rebellion was to hide in the ditch
when the piano teacher came. It was the beginning of the end of
lessons I detested. My wife, who didn't want to take swimming
lessons in seventh grade, defied her mother and got a two-piece
suit to protest. My oldest son chose rebellion of a fashion as a
middle-schooler. He dyed his sandy hair auburn. (Young, Waco
Tribune-Herald). MOVED

   KABAT-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ I am becoming a yogi. And so far,
no boo-boos or bears of any kind are involved. I am breathing
deeply, centering, stretching and twisting. What I am not doing is
jumping, jogging, lifting weights or anything else that's
strenuous. I can't do that stuff anymore. Life is very simple,
really, if you pay attention to your body. (Kabat, Waco
Tribune-Herald). MOVED

   LANE-COLUMN _ DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. _ I do not take my health news
full strength. I take it with the milk and sugar of wishful
thinking. I am selective. I ignore the salubrious medicinal effects
of Brussels sprouts, squid brain and exotic teas made of powdered
pumpkin seeds, orange rinds and just a touch of power-steering
fluid. I concentrate instead on the health-giving qualities of red
wine, select food preservatives and the orange powder on cheese
curls. (Lane, Daytona Beach News-Journal). MOVED

   BIZMAGS _ A rundown of the week's financial press. (Walker,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   TECHNOLOGY

   COXNET PTECH _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet PTECH page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET PTECH 0527: WEB PHONES _ The newest generation of cell
phones can access the Internet, vastly expanding users'
opportunities. A challenge: Stuffing meaningful content onto tiny
screens. (Katz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a three
18-pica color photos of cell phones.

   WITH: ON THE WEB _ It's a great time of the year for basketball
fans who are in the midst of enjoying the NBA playoffs. There are
plenty of Web sites available for hoops fans to visit in between
games. Here are a few. (Staff, Austin American-Statesman) Art
includes a 1-column color illustration.

   WITH: GAME CORNER _ Offering instant gratification appeal with
its ease of play, decent price point and rock-solid arcade racing
action, Beetle Buggin' is a hit (Gallaga, Austin
American-Statesman) Art includes a 1-column color photo of the game
box.

   WITH: TECHNOBUDDY _ Tiny palm-sized computers are the rage, but
they are not particularly useful. (Husted, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution.) Art includes 1 column color sig of
columnist.

   WITH: TECH NEWS _ From teenagers trying to buy beer to
sophisticated criminals trying to defraud banks, thousands of
Americans are turning to the Internet to obtain fake driver's
licenses, birth certificates and other identification documents.
(Geewax, Cox Washington Bureau)

   END OF COXNET PAGE

   TECH-HOMEGEAR _ The latest in digital home technology. This
week: The FlashBake 120. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED

   TECH-LINK _ Your link to some of the best and most interesting
sites on the Web. This week: www.internationalposter.com (Austin
American-Statesman). MOVED

   TECH-KIDGEAR _ Games for children. This week: www. riddler.com
(Austin American-Statesman) MOVED

   TECH-WORKGEAR _ The latest in digital gear. This week:
IntelliMouse Trackball. (Austin American-Statesman). MOVED

   TECH-GAMER _ Games for the console and desktop aimed at the
moderate to advanced gamer. This week: Excitebike 64. (Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED

   TECH-CENTERPIECE _ ATLANTA _ I just tried on a gazillion
swimsuits without leaving my home or removing a stitch of clothing.
There were no fluorescent lights, no tattletale three-way mirrors
and no snide saleswomen saying, ``You are going to try on that?''
It's every woman's clothing dream and it's available courtesy of
the Internet. Now, there's finally a really good reason for owning
a computer. (DiLonardo, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   TECHNOBUDDY_ Popular column about personal computing written for
the average user. (Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   TECH-TOOLS _ Reviews of the latest technology. This week:
Plantronic's Model CT10 cordless headset telephones. (Warner,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   NETWATCH _ What's new on the Web. This week: Online grocery
services. (Katz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   CYBERSCENE _ What's new on the Web. This week: shareware and
freeware. (Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   TECH-SAVVY _ Question and answer column focusing on using
computers and other technology as tools to get jobs done.
(Cleere/Rudd, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   GADGETS _ Riding a bicycle is one of the most energy-efficient
ways to get around, but using a bike to travel is sometimes
impractical. Perhaps the route is too long or too steep or perhaps
you don't have a secure place to stash your bike. The Montague
Corp.'s line of folding bicycles may help you get around some of
those obstacles. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News). MOVED

   LIFESTYLE

   NFK-CHECKITOUT _ A brief on a new web site, TV show or event for
kids. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   NFK-NEWSFLASH _ Three or four briefs of world and national news,
written for kids to understand. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
MOVED

   NFK-FEATURE _ A feature about a celebrity kid, kid's event, or
big news story explained for kids, for papers' kids or family
pages. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   CONSUMERQ&A _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Consumer Q&A. (Greig, Austin
American-Statesman) (l, a). MOVED

   SCIENCE/MEDICINE

   SPINE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The cure for paralysis from a spinal
injury is closer than ever, but that only means there's no longer a
consensus that it's impossible. Not only is it too soon to predict
when people will walk on formerly paralyzed legs, it's still
impossible to predict how medical science will make that happen,
say researchers for the prominent Miami Project to Cure Paralysis
at the University of Miami, Fla. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News).
MOVEDOLYMPHOMIA _ DAYTON, Ohio _ When researchers over the past
generation or so have talked about looking for a magic bullet to
attack cancer cells, the drug Joan Martindale took last week was
what they had in mind. (Dayton Daily News). MOVEDINTERNET _ On
consumerlab.com, which tests herbs, vitamins and other supplements.
(McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   SPOLETO _ Live coverage of the opening weekend of Spoleto
Festival USA in Charleston, SC. The sights (abstract sculpture on
plantation lawns, French trapeze artists), sounds and talk of the
southeast's best multidisciplinary arts festival. Notes from
various events as well as the private parties, one of which will be
at Revolutionary War-era house of Atlantan Eric Friberg, who serves
on Spoleto board (as well as heading the boards of the Atlanta
Opera and High Museum). Filing Monday May 29, hopefully before
noon. (Sabulis, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   NEWSSTAND _ Periodicals on the newsstands this week. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EST and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   INTERNET LINKS

   For research purposes, or to publish in your paper for readers
who'd like more information, Internet links to some of the stories
on this budget are available daily on the Cox Intranet at
http://web.coxnews.net/NRS/NTAGS/NTAGWEEK.HTM

   FEATURES MATERIAL

   So specialty editors can focus on one day's budget, CoxNet
produces themed features budgets each day. Here is the schedule:

   TODAY: Technology

   Tuesday for Wednesday: Automotive, personal finance and home &
garden

   Wednesday for Thursday: Food, CD reviews, video reviews

   Thursday for Friday: Movie reviews, travel, books and fashion

   Friday for Saturday: Religion and science & health

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   The news manager is Paul Foutch, 404-526-5429,
pfoutch(at)coxnews.com.

   The day news editor is Tom Oder, 404-526-5887,
toder(at)coxnews.com.

   The night news editor is Todd C. Duncan, 404-582-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com.

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Photo Editor Rick McKay 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com

   2/3

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
